Award.AwardTitle: Engineering novel designer glycopeptides as molecular carriers for boosting protein secretion in plant cell culture

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1605564
Xu, Jianfeng

With increasing needs for high-value protein-based therapeutics, plant cells offer a safe and cost-effective alternative bioproduction platform. However, low protein productivity is a common bottleneck in the commercialization of this technology. This project engineers plant cells to express foreign proteins that are secreted into the cell culture medium. This is advantageous as the protein is now sequestered from intracellular proteolytic degradation and can be readily recovered and purified. Fundamental knowledge gained from this research will advance our understanding of plant development, stress defense, and plant cell wall assembly. This is a highly interdisciplinary research project that will present unique learning opportunities for both graduate and undergraduate students at Arkansas State University.

The overall goal of this project is to leverage a designer molecular carrier engineering technology in developing a commercially competitive plant cell-based bioproduction platform for high-value proteins. Specifically, this project aims to exploit the unique plant Hyp-O-glycosylation 'code' that precisely directs the O-glycosylation of a proline-rich peptide, to develop novel Hyp-O-glycosylated peptides (HypGPs) that function as a molecular carrier in excreting conjoined heterologous proteins to cell culture media. The PIs will test the hypothesis that strategically designed HypGP carriers can function to improve plant cell culture productivity by boosting the secretion of several model proteins and stabilizing these products in culture media. The precise Hyp-O-glycosylation process in tobacco BY-2 cells, and the key mechanisms facilitating protein secretion will be dissected. Based on the outcome of this study, optimal HypGP design in terms of peptide sequence and chain length to achieve the highest protein yields will be established. In order to assess the practical and broader applications of the designer HypGPs for expressing larger and complex therapeutic proteins, expression of two distinct and therapeutically promising proteins, human alfa1-antitrypsin (52 kDa) and interleukin-12 (70 kDa) will be tested. Additionally, broader applicability of Hyp-O-glycosylation 'code' to engineering functional designer HypGPs in monocot rice cell culture will be investigated towards advancing our understanding about the Hyp-O-glycosylation in monocot plants and achieving high protein productivity in rice cell culture.
This award by the Biotechnology and Biochemical Engineering Program of the CBET Division is co-funded by the Systems and Synthetic Biology Program of the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences and by the Experimental Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plant cell culture has emerged as a safe and cost-effective bioproduction platform for therapeutic proteins. This project genetically engineered plant cells (tobacco cells) to produce valuable therapeutic proteins with a novel Designer Peptide (DP) tag. This DP tag is decorated with plant cell wall-specific sugars in plant cells, termed "O-glycosylation", and functions as a molecular carrier in facilitating protein secretion into the culture media and protecting the proteins from proteolytic degradation. This not only dramatically increased protein productivity by up to 1500-fold but also greatly reduced the downstream processing costs, thus promoting commercialization of plant cell culture technology for protein-based therapeutic production.  

This project elucidated the precise process for adding sugar residues onto the DP tag (DP O-glycosylation) in plant cells and dissected the key mechanism of the DP tag in promoting the secretion of fused proteins. An optimal DP design that consists of 20 tandem repeats of the "Serine-Proline" motif or (SP)20 was derived, with which the highest secreted protein yields up to 250 mg/L of a reporter green fluorescence protein was achieved. It was found that the composition of plant cell culture medium, especially nitrogen, significantly affected intracellular transport and O-glycosylation of DP-tagged proteins. In order to demonstrate the practical and broader applications of this technology, the DP tag with optimized design was applied to express larger and more complex therapeutic proteins in tobacco cells, including α1-antitrypsin, interleukin-12 and erythropoietin. All the tested proteins achieved high secreted protein yields up to 35 mg/L. When the DP tags were engineered into monocotyledonous rice cells, they were O-glycosylated with the sugar residues similar to those of dicotyledonous tobacco and Arabidopsis cells, and boosted protein secretion by at least 100-fold compared with the expression of the protein control (without a DP tag). In addition, a new discovery about the function of a special signal peptide was made. This signal peptide was found to significantly facilitate the intracellular transport and glycosylation of all the DP-tagged proteins in plant cells. This discovery has led to a new research project, aiming at engineering new therapeutic proteins with the special signal peptide in plant cells for biomedical applications. To sum up, this project has established a high-yield plant cell-based bioproduction platform for protein therapeutics. Fundamental knowledge gained about the process of DP-tag glycosylation has advanced overall understanding of the plant cell wall biopolymer assembly. This project has generated nine peer-reviewed papers and seven thesis/dissertations. Three more manuscripts are being prepared.

The interdisciplinary research in this project has provided unique experiential learning opportunities for students at Arkansas State University, especially female students, in more effectively engaging and equipping them for future STEM careers. Six graduate students (2 PhD level) and more than thirteen undergraduate students (9 female) have participated in this project and received extensive hands-on laboratory training. This project has also provided training opportunities for five minority students from a historically black university (University of Arkansas at Pine Bluff) as part of the NSF-funded Bridge to the Doctorate grant that fosters minority student research in STEM. Most of the participating students presented their research at national and state-wide conferences and won awards, such as the Philip R. White Award and Hope E. Award at the annual In Vitro Biology Meeting. It is worth mentioning that one undergraduate student with five co-authored journal publications was admitted to the very competitive PhD program at St. Jude Children's Research Hospital in fall 2019. The research of this project was also integrated into a very active and established Biotech Educational Outreach Program that serves over 1000 regional K-12 students each year. In addition, PI and co-PI organized "DNA Day" on Arkansas State University campus every year to outreach over 100 local junior high students.
